intro: Pedicularis canadensis var. fluviatilis, commonly known as the river hound's tongue, is a perennial flowering plant native to North America. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, commonly known as the broomrape family, and is characterized by its distinctive, spurred flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as along riverbanks and in woodland areas. It has a basal rosette of lance-shaped leaves and produces showy, red or orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. This variant is noted for its adaptability to wet soils and its role in supporting local pollinator populations.
